en: Le Chambon developed thanks to mining, of which we find vestiges: old buildings, tunnels and mining platform. Moreover, the preserved nature of the meandering Luech between Le Chambon and Chamboredon is a privileged habitat for beavers, grey herons, roe deer and other birds of prey that cohabitate in its wild gorges. The Mediterranean climate and the environment are the main assets of a commune which is also based on a history and a working-class culture linked to the mine, which has now been restored. Chambon is a paradise for swimming and fishing, along the Luech and its elegant bridges. This pretty village perched on a ridge or along the water offers you throughout the year the authenticity of its environmental quality. At the bend in its shady paths you can discover the remains of a glorious mining past or one of the most beautiful Tumulus of southern France (starting from the hamlet of Dieusses) To see, to do: Tumulus de l'Elzière This huge arrangement of stones probably dating from the Bronze Age was used as a burial place for several periods of our era. Remarkable for its tiered construction and built entirely of dry stone, it has no equivalent in this part of the Cevennes. You can access the site through a signposted route from the hamlet of Dieusses. Swimming & fishing in the River Luech

Le climat méditerranéen et l’environnement constituent les principaux atouts d’une commune qui s’appuie également sur une histoire et une culture ouvrière liée à la mine, aujourd’hui remise en valeur.Le Chambon est le paradis de la baignade et de la pêche, le long du Luech et de ses élégantes pontières. Ce joli village perché en crête ou au fil de l'eau vous offre tout au long de l'année l'authenticité de sa qualité environnementale.Au détour de ses sentiers ombragés vous pourrez découvrir les vestiges d'un passé minier glorieux ou encore un des plus beaux Tumulus du Sud de la France (au départ du hameau de Dieusses)A voir, à faire : Tumulus de l'Elzière Cet énorme agencement de pierres datant probablement de l'âge de Bronze a servi de sépulture pendant plusieurs périodes de notre ère. en:
Le Chambon was developed thanks to the mining industry, of which there are vestiges: old buildings, tunnels and a mining platform. In addition, the preserved nature of the meanders of the Luech between Chambon and Chamboredon is a privileged habitat for beavers, grey herons, roe deer and other birds of prey that cohabit in its wild gorges. The Mediterranean climate and the environment are the main assets of a town which also relies on a history and a working class culture linked to the mine, nowadays revived.

Le Chambon is a paradise for swimming and fishing, along the Luech and its elegant bridges. This pretty village perched on a ridge or along the water offers you the authenticity of its environmental quality all year round.
Along its shaded paths you can discover the remains of a glorious mining past or one of the most beautiful Tumulus of the South of France (from the hamlet of Dieusses)

To see, to do 

Tumulus of Elzière
This huge arrangement of stones probably dating from the Bronze Age was used as a burial ground during several periods of our era. Remarkable by its construction in steps and entirely built of dry stones, it has no equivalent in this part of the Cevennes.
You can reach the site by following a signposted route from the hamlet of Dieusses.
